I know this is a couple of years old, but the 'it brings attention' argument isn't just about it being on CNN. It's about the fact that once CNN starts talking about it, so do other people. CNN's coverage wasn't the end of the discussion.  That certainly doesn't make it an easy question to answer - you can't just assume that CNN showing burning cars will turn out to be a net good because the negative attention at the start might do more harm than any subsequent discussion it leads to. But the reverse assumption here, the one that casts it as an easy question to answer from the other direction, seems just as wrong, framing it as a choice between relative inattention (as you point out re the housing crisis for instance) and CNN's negative attention.  The choice is between relative inattention and a complex mix of attention: some of it is going to be negative and some of it will be positive, and there will be waves of responses that are positive and negative. How that calculus will shake out in a given scenario is hard to predict before it happens, and even before you see the character and reach of the waves of responses. The only thing that's pretty easy to answer is what happens without the community's violent reaction: it won't be discussed much at all. I know it's not the usual way of doing things to make a video about events from a year and a half ago. But I find it's hard to say anything very worthwhile about current events. You never know the whole story yet, and you haven't had any time to think about it. So what you end up doing is 'reacting,' i.e. spewing your first-pass gut feelings. And that's what a lot of YouTube commentary is: 'reactions.'  Maybe a better way to talk about current events is to look at recent history. You can get a fuller story, and you have some retrospective distance. That's what I'm trying to do in this video: not just to tell the history of the Baltimore uprising but also to better understand similar uprisings that are likely to occur in the years ahead.
